segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings Optional subsystems security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings Optional subsystems security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings: Optional subsystems security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the System settings: Optional subsystems security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which subsystems support your applications.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which subsystems support your applications.

segment.source: You can use this security setting to specify as many subsystems as your environment demands.
segment.target: You can use this security setting to specify as many subsystems as your environment demands.

segment.source: The subsystem introduces a security risk that is related to processes that can potentially persist across logons.
segment.target: The subsystem introduces a security risk that is related to processes that can potentially persist across logons.

segment.source: If a user starts a process and then logs out, the next user who logs on to the system might access the process that the previous user started.
segment.target: If a user starts a process and then logs out, the next user who logs on to the system might access the process that the previous user started.

segment.source: This is dangerous, because the process started by the first user can retain that user's system user rights; therefore, anything that the second user does using that process is performed with the user rights of the first user.
segment.target: This is dangerous, because the process started by the first user can retain that user's system user rights; therefore, anything that the second user does using that process is performed with the user rights of the first user.

segment.source: This makes it difficult to trace who creates processes and objects, which is essential for post-security incident forensics.
segment.target: This makes it difficult to trace who creates processes and objects, which is essential for post-security incident forensics.

segment.source: Set this policy setting to a null value.
segment.target: Set this policy setting to a null value.

segment.source: The default value is POSIX, so applications that rely on the POSIX subsystem will no longer run.
segment.target: The default value is POSIX, so applications that rely on the POSIX subsystem will no longer run.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft Services for UNIX 3.0 installs an updated version of the POSIX subsystem.
segment.target: For example, Microsoft Services for UNIX 3.0 installs an updated version of the POSIX subsystem.

segment.source: Reset this policy setting in Group Policy for any servers that use Services for UNIX 3.0.
segment.target: Reset this policy setting in Group Policy for any servers that use Services for UNIX 3.0.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: The POSIX subsystem is an Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines a set of operating system services.
segment.target: The POSIX subsystem is an Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers (IEEE) standard that defines a set of operating system services.

segment.source: The POSIX subsystem is required if the server supports applications that use that subsystem.
segment.target: The POSIX subsystem is required if the server supports applications that use that subsystem.

segment.source: The POSIX subsystem introduces a security risk that relates to processes that can potentially persist across logons.
segment.target: The POSIX subsystem introduces a security risk that relates to processes that can potentially persist across logons.

segment.source: If a user starts a process and then logs out, there is a potential that the next user who logs on to the computer could access the previous user's process.
segment.target: If a user starts a process and then logs out, there is a potential that the next user who logs on to the computer could access the previous user's process.

segment.source: This would allow the second user to take actions on the process by using the privileges of the first user.
segment.target: This would allow the second user to take actions on the process by using the privileges of the first user.

segment.source: Configure the System settings: Optional subsystems setting to a null value.
segment.target: Configure the System settings: Optional subsystems setting to a null value.

segment.source: Applications that rely on the POSIX subsystem no longer operate.
segment.target: Applications that rely on the POSIX subsystem no longer operate.

segment.source: For example, Microsoft Services for UNIX (SFU) installs an updated version of the POSIX subsystem that is required, so you must reconfigure this setting in Group Policy for any servers that use SFU.
segment.target: For example, Microsoft Services for UNIX (SFU) installs an updated version of the POSIX subsystem that is required, so you must reconfigure this setting in Group Policy for any servers that use SFU.
